title: Exciting Talks at R-Ladies Rome: First Half of the Year
text:
We are thrilled to look back at the first half of the year and share the exciting talks that R-Ladies Rome has hosted. It has been an incredible journey, filled with amazing speakers who have shared their knowledge and insights on various topics related to R programming.
The year kicked off with Julia Silge‚Äôs captivating talk on MLOps with Vetiver, followed by Mine Cetinkaya-Rundel‚Äôs informative presentation on RLadies Quarto. Isabella Velasquez then took the stage and shared with us What‚Äôs new in the tidyverse. Our series of inspiring talks continued with Jacqueline Buros and Federica Gazzelloni wrapping up the initial set of events with a thought-provoking discussion on Deterministic modeling of infectious diseases and Bayesian modeling of infectious diseases.
As we continued to grow, we were excited to welcome Jon Harmon, the first male speaker, who engaged us with his talk on time zone adjustments and his insightful presentation titled ‚ÄúWhy I Hate Summer Time: Coordinating a Global Community of Learners.‚Äù
But we didn‚Äôt stop there! The first half of the year concluded with two more exciting events. We had the privilege of hosting Dr.¬†Simina Boca, who shared her expertise on Data Science Best Practices. Additionally, Dr.¬†Laura Kahn enlightened us with her talk on ‚ÄúOne Health and the Politics of Coronaviruses.‚Äù
We are incredibly grateful to all our speakers for their passion and dedication in sharing their expertise with our community. Their talks have enriched our knowledge and inspired us to continue exploring the vast world of R programming.
To those who missed any of these enlightening talks, fear not! You can find the presentation materials on our website. If you have any inquiries or want more information, don‚Äôt hesitate to reach out to us at rome@rladies.org.
The first half of the year has been phenomenal, but we are just getting started! Stay tuned for more exciting events and speakers in the future. Together, we will continue to foster a vibrant community that supports and empowers each other in the world of R programming.

title: Introduction
text:

title: RLadies Quarto
text:
Registered Attendees (86)
February 2023 speaker is Mine √áetinkaya-Rundel, Professor of the Practice at Duke University and Developer Educator at Posit PBC. Her work focuses on innovation in statistics and data science pedagogy, with an emphasis on computing, reproducible research, and student-centered learning. She is also involved in the OpenIntro project, co-authoring four open-source introductory statistics textbooks, and is a Fellow of the ASA and Elected Member of the ISI.
In the talk, she introduces Quarto, an open-source publishing system that is designed for scientific and technical content. Built on top of the R Markdown ecosystem, it provides a unified and extended platform for publishing technical content. She will be discussing and demonstrating how she uses Quarto for authoring, teaching, and collaborating.

If you‚Äôre interested in learning more about Quarto and how it can be used for technical publishing, be sure to check out the talk at https://youtu.be/p7Hxu4coDl8.
More about Quarto: quarto-tip-a-day
Material of the talk: quarto-rladies-rome

title: Data Science Best Practices
text:
Registered Attendees (66)
June 12, 2023 speaker is Dr.¬†Simina Boca, statistician and data scientist who has experience in both academia and industry. She has worked in the analysis of omics data, population genetics, precision medicine, and early-phase drug development. Dr.¬†Boca has taught courses and presented tutorials using R and has developed a number of R packages. She was a co-organizer for R-Ladies DC in 2021 and 2022.
During her presentation, Dr.¬†Boca discussed the different stages of data analysis, offering expert advice on how to effectively organize and manage data science projects. She also delved into the importance of reproducible research, highlighting key principles and best practices for ensuring that research could be replicated and verified.

But that wasn‚Äôt all! Dr.¬†Boca provided an introduction to exploratory data analysis, discussing basic principles and techniques for visualizing and analyzing data. Attendees gained valuable insights into the process of data analysis, as well as practical tips and strategies for managing data science projects and conducting reproducible research.

title: Why I Hate Summer Time: Coordinating a Global Community of Learners
text:
Registered Attendees (38)
May 2023 speaker is Jon Harmon, dedicated leader who runs the R4DS Online Learning Community to help others improve their R skills. He provides a supportive and collaborative environment for R learners of all skill levels to learn and grow through book clubs and question-answering. Jon is also a freelance R package developer who uses his expertise to help others in the community develop their own R packages and improve their coding skills.
In this talk, Jon Harmon shares valuable insights and practical tips for managing time zones and scheduling events for a global audience. As the Chief Community Manager of R4DS Online Learning Community, Jon drew from his experience of leading a global community of R enthusiasts at all skill levels, working together to improve their abilities. Attendees had the opportunity to learn from Jon‚Äôs leadership and guidance, network with other R learners and experts, and enhance their understanding of time zones and R. It was an incredible opportunity not to be missed!

Time zone changing time issues can be a major challenge when scheduling events for a global audience. With different time zones, daylight saving time changes, and varying work schedules, it can be difficult to find a time that works for everyone. This can lead to confusion, missed meetings, and frustration for both organizers and attendees. In his talk, Jon Harmon provided valuable insights and practical tips for managing time zones and scheduling events to help overcome these challenges. Attendees learned how to navigate time zone differences, avoid scheduling conflicts, and ensure that everyone is on the same page when it comes to meeting times.

title: MLOps with vetiver
text:
Registered Attendees (53)
January 2023 speaker is Julia Silge, data scientist and software engineer at Posit PBC, with a PhD in astrophysics. Julia is an author, international keynote speaker, and practitioner in data analysis and machine learning.
In the talk, she covers the challenges of deploying and maintaining machine learning models and introduces the principles of MLOps. She also discusses the various tasks and components involved in MLOps and demonstrates how to get started with vetiver, a framework for MLOps tasks in R. The video provides a great resource for those interested in learning more about MLOps and how to implement it in their own projects.

The process of training a machine learning or statistical model is well understood by many data scientists. However, the task of creating a strategy to deploy and maintain that model can be overwhelming. This is where Machine Learning Operations (MLOps) comes in.
MLOps is a set of principles and practices that can be used to create a practical strategy for deploying and maintaining machine learning models.
Material of the talk: mlops-r-ladies-rome

title: What‚Äôs new in the tidyverse
text:
Registered Attendees (78)
March 2023 speaker is Isabella Velasquez, R enthusiast who first learned the programming language during her MSc in Analytics. She has experience in data analysis, research, and developing infrastructure to support the use of data. Currently, she works on the Posit (formerly RStudio) Marketing team, creating content to support and strengthen data science teams.
In the talk, she covers the numerous updates and new features added to the tidyverse, everything from the latest string-separating functions to new joins, and show you how these updates can make your life as a data scientist more streamlined and intuitive.

If you‚Äôre an R user, you‚Äôre probably familiar with the tidyverse - a collection of packages that have transformed the way we handle data wrangling, visualization, and analysis.
The tidyverse is a collection of open-source R packages designed for data science. It was developed by Hadley Wickham and his team at RStudio, and it includes packages for data manipulation, visualization, modeling, and programming.
The tidyverse emphasizes a consistent and intuitive syntax, making it easier for users to work with data and create reproducible analyses. Some of the most popular packages in the tidyverse include dplyr, ggplot2, tidyr, and purrr. Overall, the tidyverse has become a widely-used and powerful tool for data scientists and analysts working with R.
Material of the talk: Whats New in the Tidyverse

title: Modeling infectious diseases
text:
Registered Attendees (37) in Partnership with R-Ladies NYC Registered Attendees (39)
April 2023 speakers are Jacqueline Buros, experienced in biostatistics and bioinformatics, she is the author of the survivalstan package and a contributor to the rstanarm package, and Federica Gazzelloni, independent researcher and statistician, author the Oregonfrogs package.
In this talk a deterministic and a Bayesian version of the SIR model is presented.

The deterministic SIR model is a mathematical model used to understand the spread of infectious diseases in a population, assuming that the population is homogeneous and the disease spreads at a constant rate. The Bayesian SIR model, on the other hand, incorporates uncertainty and variability in the model parameters, allowing for more accurate predictions and better decision-making. It uses Bayesian inference to estimate the probability distribution of the model parameters, given the observed data.
Material of the talk:

deterministic-sir-model-with-r
r-ladies-sir-model

title: One Health and the Politics of Coronaviruses
text:
Registered Attendees (29)
June 30, 2023 speaker is Dr. Laura Kahn.
If you‚Äôre a researcher involved in improving public health or interested in the fascinating world of zoonotic diseases, you won‚Äôt want to miss the enlightening talk by Dr. Laura Kahn.
In this video Dr.¬†Laura Kahn, physician, author, and educator, will share her latest research findings and insights from her upcoming book One Health and the Politics of Coronaviruses. With her extensive experience and dedication to transforming global health approaches, Dr.¬†Kahn‚Äôs work has significantly contributed to the development of the One Health Initiative. She spent nearly 20 years as a research scholar at the Program on Science and Global Security at Princeton University School of Public and International Affairs, where her innovative work laid the groundwork for this important initiative.

Gain a deeper understanding of the interconnectedness between human, animal, and environmental health, particularly in relation to emerging zoonotic diseases like coronaviruses. Dr.¬†Kahn‚Äôs expertise and groundbreaking research shed light on this crucial topic, offering valuable insights and thought-provoking perspectives. To further explore the subject, we recommend visiting the One Health Initiative website (http://www.onehealthinitiative.com) for additional resources and information. title: R-Ladies Rome
text:
Welcome to R-Ladies Rome, local chapter of R-Ladies Global, an organization that promotes gender diversity in the R programming community worldwide. Our community is designed to develop our members‚Äô R skills and knowledge through social, collaborative learning and sharing, supporting minority identity access to STEM skills and careers, the Free Software Movement, and contributing to the global R community.

At R-Ladies Rome, we welcome members of all R proficiency levels, whether you‚Äôre a new or aspiring R user, or an experienced R programmer interested in mentoring, networking, and expert up-skilling. Our priority is to provide a safe community space for anyone identifying as a minority gender who is interested in working with R. We are pro-actively inclusive of queer, trans, and all minority identities, with additional sensitivity to intersectional identities.
Our community meets regularly in person or virtually to learn about the R programming language, algorithms, and advanced tools. We organize events such as workshops, meetups, and conferences to teach R programming skills, share knowledge and experiences, and build a community of R users. We also provide training and development opportunities for our members, including online courses, mentorship programs, and other resources to help members improve their R programming skills.
R-Ladies Rome is committed to research and advocacy efforts related to gender diversity in the R community. We conduct surveys, publish reports, and advocate for policies and practices that promote gender diversity and inclusion. We also provide a platform for our members to share their experiences and contribute to the global R community.
Join us today and become a part of our supportive community of R users. You can access our presentations, R scripts, and projects on our GitHub account and follow us on Twitter to stay up to date about R-Ladies news. Remember, there is no cost or charge to participate in any of our R-Ladies communities around the world.

title: About
text: R-Ladies began as a meetup group in San Francisco in 2012 when Gabriela de Queiroz founded the first chapter and organized the first event. Over the next three years, three more groups started following this example. After the useR! conference in 2016, where Gabriela and other organizers met in person, R-Ladies Global was co-founded by several active community members. Since then, the organization has experienced massive and rapid growth, with the number of R-Ladies chapters increasing significantly. Today, R-Ladies has 218 chapters in 29 countries and over 3943 events contributing to promote gender diversity in the R community.
